critique: This document is an executive order from 1948 that outlines regulations for additional compensation to US personnel working outside the continental US or in Alaska, as well as salary differentials for Foreign Service staff and employees serving at certain posts. It also addresses unhealthful foreign posts. The order primarily deals with logistical and administrative matters related to compensating government employees working in challenging or remote locations. There is no direct impact on immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. The order does not explicitly expand executive power, but it does delegate authority to the Secretary of State and the Civil Service Commission to designate places and fix rates of compensation. It also does not seem to have any impact on economic regulation. The document does not seem to have any ideological tilt.
